description: From Late Middle English fragment, from Latin fragmentum (“a fragment, remnant”).

entries.meaning: A part broken off; a small, detached portion; an imperfect part, either physically or not
examples: a fragment of an ancient writing
I heard a small fragment of the conversation.

entries.meaning: (grammar) A sentence not containing a subject or a predicate.
(Internet) A portion of a URL referring to a subordinate resource or anchor (such as a specific point on a web page), introduced by the # sign.
examples: The URL www.example.com/home#recent ends with a fragment.

verbs.description: fragment (third-person singular simple present fragments, present participle fragmenting, simple past and past participle fragmented)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to be broken into pieces.
(transitive, computing) To break up and disperse (a file) into non-contiguous areas of a disk.
